text: Amounts may not total due to rounding.
For more information on reserve build (release), see note A on slide 31.

Pretax, pre-provision income and Return on average tangible common shareholders' equity are non-GAAP financial measures. For more information and a reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure, see note B on slide 31. For important presentation information about these measures, see slide 34.
In Consumer Banking, added ~360,000 net new checking accounts, marking 23 consecutive quarters of growth.
Added ~1 million credit card accounts in Consumer Banking.
Consumer Banking reported record consumer investment assets of $497B, up 28% YoY, with 3.9MM accounts, up 4%.
Consumer Banking saw 14 consecutive quarters of Small Business loan growth, with Practice Solutions loan balances up 11% YoY.
In Global Wealth & Investment Management, added ~5,500 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank.
Opened ~30,000 new bank accounts in Global Wealth & Investment Management, with over 60% of clients having a banking relationship.
Global Wealth & Investment Management recorded client balances of $4.2T, up 18% YoY.
Year-to-date AUM flows in Global Wealth & Investment Management were $57B, up 30% YoY.
Total deposits, loans, and investment balances across the company reached $5.9T.
Total net wealth spectrum flows since 3Q23 amounted to $62B.
Global Banking ranked #3 in investment banking fees.
Grew total year-to-date investment banking fees by 27% YoY to $4.5B in Global Banking.
Global Banking grew Middle Market average loans by 5% YoY and average deposits by 9% YoY.
Global Markets achieved 10 consecutive quarters of YoY sales and trading revenue growth.
Global Markets reported the highest 3Q sales and trading revenue in over a decade.
Global Markets had record YTD Equities sales and trading revenue.
Global Markets recorded average loan balances of $141B, up 7% YoY, marking 16 consecutive quarters of growth.
Digital adoption in the Consumer segment is 77%.
Digital adoption in GWIM is 84% for Merrill and 92% for Private Bank.
Digital adoption in Global Banking is 87%.
There are 48MM digital active users, a 4% increase YoY.
Digital logins totaled 3.6B, up 11% YoY.
There are 20MM active Erica users, up 5% YoY.
There are 741K digital active households in GWIM, a 4% increase YoY.
Digital logins in GWIM reached 86MM, up 26% YoY.
Digital wallet volume was $547MM, a 54% increase YoY.
There were 2MM mobile app sign-ins, an increase of 25% YoY.
CashPro app payments totaled $283B, up 47% YoY.
Over $6T in capital markets orders were processed on the Deal Central platform over the past 12 months.
There are 23MM active Zelle users, with 256MM Zelle sent transactions, which is 2.7x more than checks written.
75% of eligible Merrill bank and brokerage accounts were opened through digital onboarding.
75% of eligible checks were deposited through automated channels.
72% of commercial cardholders use Global Card Access.
There were 476K self-service card requests, leading to a 17% reduction in card call volume.
Comparisons are to 3Q23, unless otherwise noted.
Net income was $6.9B, with diluted earnings per share of $0.81.
Return on Equity (ROE) was 9.4%, and Return on Tangible Common Equity (ROTCE) was 12.8%.

Revenue, net of interest expense, of $25.3B ($25.5B FTE) increased $0.2B, or 1%, reflecting higher asset management and investment banking fees, as well as sales and trading revenue and lower net interest income (NII).
Net Interest Income (NII) of $14.0B ($14.1B FTE) decreased $0.4B, or 3%, as higher deposit costs more than offset higher asset yields and loan growth.
Provision for credit losses of $1.5B was flat compared to 2Q24 and up from $1.2B in 3Q23.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) of $1.5B were flat to 2Q24 and increased from 3Q23, driven primarily by commercial and credit card.
Net reserve build was $8MM vs. a net reserve release of $25MM in 2Q24 and a net reserve build of $303MM in 3Q23.
Noninterest expense of $16.5B increased $0.6B, or 4%, driven primarily by revenue-related expenses.
The balance sheet remained strong, with average deposits of $1.92T increasing by $45B (2%) and average loans and leases of $1.06T increasing by $13B (1%).
Average Global Liquidity Sources were $947B.
Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) capital was $200B, an increase of $2B from 2Q24.
Returned $5.6B to shareholders, including $2.0B in common dividends and $3.5B in common stock repurchases.
The quarterly common dividend per share was increased by 8%.
CET1 ratio of 11.8% decreased 10 bps from 2Q24 and is 112 bps above the new regulatory minimum, effective Oct. 1, 2024.
All data is on an end-of-period (EOP) basis unless otherwise noted.
The CET1 ratio of 11.8% decreased 10 bps from 2Q24, with CET1 capital increasing by $2B to $200B and Standardized RWA increasing by $29B to $1.69T.
Book value per share of $35.37 improved 8% from 3Q23.
Tangible book value per share of $26.25 improved 10% from 3Q23.
Average Global Liquidity Sources of $947B increased by $38B compared to 2Q24.
Net interest income (FTE) was $14.1B in 3Q24.

NII increased $0.3B from 2Q24, driven by fixed-rate asset repricing, higher NII related to Global Markets (GM) activity, and one additional day of interest accrual, partially offset by higher deposit costs.
NII decreased $0.4B YoY, as higher deposit costs more than offset higher asset yields, higher NII related to GM activity, and loan growth.
Net interest yield was 1.92%, a decrease of 1 bp from 2Q24 and 19 bps YoY.
Excluding Global Markets, net interest yield was 2.40%.
As of September 30, 2024, a -100 bps parallel shift in the interest rate yield curve was estimated to reduce net interest income by $2.7B over the next 12 months.
3Q24 noninterest expense was $16.5B.
Noninterest expense increased $0.2B, or 1%, vs. 2Q24, driven primarily by higher revenue-related expenses and investments in the franchise, including technology.
Noninterest expense increased $0.6B, or 4%, vs. 3Q23, driven primarily by revenue-related expenses and investments in the franchise, including people and technology.
Total net charge-offs of $1.5B were flat vs. 2Q24.
Consumer net charge-offs of $1.0B decreased $15MM, driven by lower credit card losses, with the credit card loss rate at 3.70% in 3Q24 vs. 3.88% in 2Q24.
Commercial net charge-offs of $490MM increased $16MM, with commercial real estate NCOs declining $101MM and commercial and industrial NCOs increasing $111MM.
The net charge-off ratio of 0.58% decreased 1 bp from 2Q24.
Provision for credit losses of $1.5B increased $34MM vs. 2Q24, reflecting a net reserve build of $8MM in 3Q24 versus a net reserve release of $25MM in 2Q24.
Allowance for loan and lease losses of $13.3B represented 1.24% of total loans and leases.
Total allowance of $14.4B included $1.1B for unfunded commitments.
Nonperforming loans (NPLs) of $5.6B increased $0.2B from 2Q24.
Net income was $2.7B.
Revenue of $10.4B decreased 1% from 3Q23.
Provision for credit losses of $1.3B decreased $95MM, or 7%, from 3Q23.
Net reserve build was $127MM vs. $486MM in 3Q23.
Net charge-offs of $1.2B increased $264MM from 3Q23, driven by credit card.
Noninterest expense of $5.5B increased 5% compared to 3Q23, driven by investments in the business, including people and technology, resulting in an efficiency ratio of 53%.
Average deposits of $938B decreased $42B, or 4%, from 3Q23, with 58% of deposits in checking accounts and 92% being primary accounts.
Average loans and leases of $314B increased $3B, or 1%, from 3Q23.
Combined credit / debit card spend of $232B increased 3% from 3Q23.
Record consumer investment assets of $497B grew $109B, or 28%, from 3Q23, driven by higher market valuations and $29B of net client flows from new and existing clients.
There are 3.9MM consumer investment accounts, up 4%.
11.2MM clients are enrolled in Preferred Rewards, up 4% from 3Q23, with a 99% annualized retention rate.
77% of households are digitally active, up from 74% in 3Q23.
Net income of $1.1B.
Revenue of $5.8B increased 8% from 3Q23, driven by 14% higher asset management fees, due to higher market levels and strong AUM flows.
Noninterest expense of $4.3B increased 10% vs. 3Q23, driven primarily by revenue-related incentives.
Client balances of $4.2T increased 18% from 3Q23, driven by higher market valuations and positive net client flows.
AUM flows of $21B in 3Q24; $65B since 3Q23.
Over 60% of clients have a banking relationship.
Average deposits of $280B decreased $12B, or 4%, from 3Q23; rate paid on deposits declined 1 bp from 2Q24.
Average loans and leases of $225B increased $7B, or 3%, from 3Q23.
Added ~5,500 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank in 3Q24.
84% of GWIM households/relationships are digitally active across the enterprise, up from 83% in 3Q23.
Net income of $1.9B.
Revenue of $5.8B decreased 6% from 3Q23, driven primarily by lower net interest income.
Total Corporation investment banking fees (ex. self-led) of $1.4B increased 18% vs. 3Q23; ranked #3 in investment banking fee ranking.
Provision for credit losses of $229MM vs. $235MM in 2Q24 and a provision benefit of $119MM in 3Q23.
Net charge-offs of $358MM were relatively flat vs. 2Q24 and increased $338MM from 3Q23, driven by corporate and commercial losses and commercial real estate office.
Net reserve release of $129MM vs. $111MM in 2Q24 and $139MM in 3Q23.
Noninterest expense of $3.0B increased 7% vs. 3Q23, driven by continued investments in the business, including people and technology.
Average deposits of $550B increased $45B, or 9%, from 3Q23.
Average loans and leases of $371B decreased $5B, or 1%, from 3Q23.
Net income of $1.5B ($1.6B excluding net DVA).
Revenue of $5.6B increased 14% from 3Q23, driven by higher sales and trading revenue and investment banking fees.
Sales and trading revenue of $4.9B increased 12% from 3Q23, both including and excluding net DVA.
FICC revenue increased 8%, to $2.9B, driven primarily by improved client activity and trading performance in currencies and interest rate products.
Equities revenue increased 18%, to $2.0B, driven by strong client activity and trading performance in cash and derivatives.
Noninterest expense of $3.4B increased 6% vs. 3Q23, driven by higher revenue-related expenses and investments in the business, including technology.
Average VaR of $78MM in 3Q24.
All Other primarily consists of asset and liability management (ALM) activities, liquidating businesses, and certain expenses not otherwise allocated to a business segment.
Net loss of $0.3B.
Revenue of ($2.2B) declined $0.5B from 3Q23 and included a charge in other income of approximately $0.2B related to Visa's increase in its litigation escrow account.
Noninterest expense of $0.2B decreased $0.4B from 3Q23, driven primarily by lower costs associated with a liquidating business.
Total corporate effective tax rate (ETR) for the quarter was approximately 6%.
Excluding discrete tax items and recurring tax credits primarily related to investments in renewable energy and affordable housing, the ETR would have been approximately 24%.
Commercial Real Estate Loans represent 6.4% of Total Loans and Leases.
Total Commercial Real Estate loans amount to approximately $68B.

Key characteristics of the Office portfolio ($15.8B): ~75% Class A property type, ~55% origination LTV, ~11% NPL to loans, $5.1B reservable criticized exposure with ~80% LTV, and 3Q24 NCOs of $0.2B (down $0.1B vs. 2Q24).
Bank of America is ranked #1 in U.S. Retail Deposit Market Share.
Deposits in excess of loans were $855B in 3Q24.
Excess deposits are stored in cash and investment securities, with 52% in cash and AFS and 48% in HTM in 3Q24.
Cash levels of $295B remained well above the pre-pandemic level of $162B in 4Q19.
AFS securities are mostly hedged with floating rate swaps, substantially eliminating regulatory capital impacts, with a duration of less than 0.5 years.
The HTM securities book has declined $116B since peaking at $683B in 3Q21; it is down $36B vs. 3Q23 and $10B vs. 2Q24.
Blended cash and securities yield is relatively flat vs. 2Q24 and is 153 bps above the deposit rate paid.
Holds the No. 1 position in estimated U.S. Retail Deposits and is the No. 1 Small Business Lender.
Recognized as Best Bank in North America and Best Bank in the U.S.
Named Best Bank in the U.S. for Small and Medium Enterprises.
Certified by J.D. Power for Outstanding Client Satisfaction with Customer Financial Health Support – Banking & Payments.
Recognized with multiple leadership awards, including No. 1 on Forbes' Top Women Wealth Advisors and Barron's Top 1200 Wealth Financial Advisors List in 2024.
Holds No. 1 position in Managed Personal Trust AUM.
Awarded Best Private Bank (U.S.) and Best Private Bank for Philanthropic Services and Sustainable Investing.
Named Best Private Bank in the Nation and for Family Office, OCIO, Digital Innovation, and Excellence in Philanthropy Services.
Recognized as World's Most Innovative Bank - 2024.
Awarded World's Best Bank for Trade Finance and FX payments; North America's Best Digital Bank and Best Bank for Sustainable Finance.
Named 2023 Best Bank for Cash & Liquidity Management and Best Mobile Technology Solution for Treasury: CashPro App.
Received accolades for Best Global Bank for Transaction Banking and Collections.
Earned a Model Bank Award for Reimagining Trade & Supply Chain Finance for CashPro Supply Chain Solutions.
Holds relationships with 78% of the Global Fortune 500 and 95% of the U.S. Fortune 1,000.
Recognized as World's Best Bank for Markets and FX Payments.

Named Americas Derivatives House of the Year, Equity Derivatives House of the Year, Commodity Derivatives Bank of the Year, Research and Strategy House of the Year, and Derivatives Clearing Bank of the Year.
A. Reserve build (or release) is calculated by subtracting net charge-offs from the provision for credit losses.
B. Pretax, pre-provision income (PTPI) is a non-GAAP financial measure calculated by adjusting pretax income to add back provision for credit losses.
C. Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) include cash and high-quality, liquid, unencumbered securities readily available to meet funding requirements.

D. Interest rate sensitivity as of September 30, 2024, reflects the potential pretax impact to forecasted net interest income over the next 12 months from a parallel shock to the market-based forward curve.
E. Revenue for all periods included net debit valuation adjustments (DVA) on derivatives.
F. VaR model uses a historical simulation approach based on three years of historical data and an expected shortfall methodology equivalent to a 99% confidence level.
(A) Estimated U.S. retail deposits based on June 30, 2024 FDIC deposit data.
(B) FDIC, 2Q24.
(C) Global Finance, April 2024.
(D) Global Finance, October 2023.
(E) J.D. Power 2024 Financial Health Support Certification is based on exceeding customer experience benchmarks using client surveys and a best practices verification.
(F) Global Finance, 2024.
(G) Family Wealth Report, 2024.
(H) Global Private Banker, 2024.
(I) Euromoney, 2024.
(J) Treasury Management International, 2024.
(K) Celent, 2024.
(L) Coalition Greenwich, 2023.
(M) GlobalCapital, 2024.

The Corporation may present certain non-GAAP financial measures to provide additional clarity in understanding its results of operations and trends.
The Corporation presents certain key financial and nonfinancial performance indicators (KPIs) that management uses when assessing consolidated and/or segment results.
The Corporation also views net interest income and related ratios on a fully taxable-equivalent (FTE) basis, which is a non-GAAP financial measure, for comparative purposes.
